Women in daytime = whores. At least, I think theyâ€™re the same. I dunno. Itâ€™s hard for me to figure it all out since Iâ€™m just a woman. Either Iâ€™ve been watching too much daytime or itâ€™s the peyoteâ€¦ (just kidding on the last part, though given what some shows are doing to daytime women and viewers as a consequence, a little peyote might make daytime shows go down a little easier).

General Hospital

Iâ€™m all about the â€˜I told you soâ€™ lately and I want to hand one out to the writers of GH. Iâ€™ve never been impressed with the casting of James Franco in the role of â€˜Francoâ€™ and have been horrified by the drooling and self-congratulating linked to the casting of JF in the role. The fact that the character was named Franco was enough to tell me about the lack of creativity attached his development. It seemed to be all about stunt casting and the hope that a primetime/big screen actor could save GH from falling ratings.

It feels as if GHâ€™s PTB were so convinced that negative stereotypes about daytime viewers were real, the stereotype that weâ€™re just a bunch of sex-starved panty-clinching rubes, who lick our screens whenever a hot male actor is featured, that casting JF as â€˜Francoâ€™ made sense! As if we donâ€™t already have enough testosterone filled doom and gloom on screen! (As for that screen licking part, I freely admit that I do think about licking the screen when Jason Thompsonâ€™s Patrick is on, but hell, who doesnâ€™t?) The idea that â€œFrancoâ€ would cause us to swoon was as big a fallacy as almost everything else the GH writers have offered us by way of propping the Suckpranos storyline. I donâ€™t want to see one more character, stunt casting or otherwise, sacrificed on the altar of the mob boys.

Give Olivia her brain back. She was such a strong vibrant character for so long and now sheâ€™s a walking-talking mess. All the daydreaming about Sonny makes me ill. If I had to worry about Sonny putting a bullet in my kidâ€™s head because my kid was a cop working to make the world safe? I wouldnâ€™t be able to daydream about having sex with the guy or daydream about him holding my hand. I wouldnâ€™t even daydream about spitting on the guy if he was on fire! Whatâ€™s wrong with this woman? Whatâ€™s with her libido? Sonny rocked her world over two decades ago, bedded and nearly wedded her cousin â€“ swore his eternal love for Kate before the world while barely noticing or remembering Olivia, and sheâ€™s still lusting for him? STOP! IT!

Quit making Carly an idiot who treats Jaxâ€™s child as Sonnyâ€™s future â€˜kidnapped baitâ€™ child. Itâ€™s disgusting. Notice that when Carly was listing off the children who were protected by Sonnyâ€™s grace, she included Josslyn, and not Molly? STOP IT!

STOP making Lulu fall for the mob boys and/or supporting them to the point of even trying to convince the police that they really deserve to be set free instead of in prison where they belong. Stop making her fall for anyone connected, even tangentially, to the mob boys. Whatever those mob boys have going on below the belt must be some powerful mojo! And itâ€™s demeaning to us all.

Quit making me feel sorry for Rebecca â€œNotEmilyâ€ Shaw by having her actually be the voice of logic and reason before you ship her off. I really resent you for this one, GH writers. Iâ€™m an avowed â€˜Remilyâ€™ hater and to leave me cheering for her is one of your worse offenses, yet. Even still, I grew tired of the â€œLiz is a slutâ€™ mantra she had going â€“ not that I disagree with the sentiment, just the constant expression of it. I did enjoy the fact that she continued to remind Liz that her house of cards would soon fold. The sendoff for Rebecca, the Emily- clone was perfect, by having her make friends with a Zander cloneâ€¦ Chad Brannon was pretty darned delicious looking. When his clone character drops Rebecca off in Paris, have him come back! Patrickâ€™s stalker ex could use a good hook up â€“ then again, so could Matt Drake, who spends far too much time trying to convince Robin that her marriage is in trouble!

Maxie, Maxie, Maxieâ€¦ REALLY? Sheâ€™s gives herself to Franco for the sake of getting him to agree to help her out professionally? Then she tries to pimp out Spinelli to make herself feel better? She gives relationship advice to Max and Diane about â€˜balanced cheatingâ€™? Maxelli, Scrubs Love, and Jax and Carly were the only interesting things GH had going in its favor and the writers are slowly dismantling all three. Speaking ofâ€¦

For the love of all thatâ€™s soap-holyâ€¦ give me a Scrubs storyline that has nothing to do with old girlfriends crawling out of the woodwork! Yeah, yeahâ€¦ Patrick puts it on â€™emâ€¦ they canâ€™t get enoughâ€¦ once you go Patrick, you never go backâ€¦ Even though I can believe that his arrogant aloof treatment of women made them want him more, Iâ€™m getting tired of women who are attracted to him on that basis. The writers made the courageous decision to make him a happy family man, now I wish theyâ€™d make the courageous decision to create family driven storytelling around the Scorpio-Drake clan. What makes Patrick attractive is that heâ€™s a man who loves his wife and child. Having him betray them would destroy that. Leave something thatâ€™s still a little pure and just for us.

Iâ€™d love it if the GH powers that be would stop treating women (onscreen) like a bunch of â€˜spare partsâ€™ waiting to be traded by GH males, as theyâ€™re needed. Bringing on stellar actors like James Franco canâ€™t cover the holes in plots, the obsession with the dark arts of the mob boys, or the weak female characters who arenâ€™t just damaged- theyâ€™re damned deranged. Treating your viewers like sex-starved fiends whoâ€™ll gladly buy what youâ€™re selling wonâ€™t help either. I know itâ€™s not just my perspective that GH has lost what made it greatâ€¦ Iâ€™ve seen the ratings. GH is hemorrhaging viewers and the great â€˜Francoâ€™ (onscreen Franco) doesnâ€™t deliver a big enough draw to stop it:

So why am I still watching? I donâ€™t think soap fans like me want too much. We just want a balance. How about 2 smart women for every woman who is lobotomized for the sake of the dark storylines? Iâ€™m hoping Scrubs will survive and find a real storyline and that the writers will give us a storyline about them that will engage the audience without either of them cheating, Iâ€™ve FINALLY gotten the Mac and Alexis pairing Iâ€™ve been pimping for, through 2009 (donâ€™t think Iâ€™m not grateful, just realize Iâ€™m not fully satisfied. Theyâ€™re off to a great start, and I need MORE). Dare I hope that Mac/Alexis/Robert/Anna/Robin/Patrick would be able to restore law and order to PC and that they turn the town around and take down the real bad guys? Iâ€™m hoping that smart, funny, and strong-if-not-neurotic, women like Robin and Alexis (and yes, even Diane) will be allowed to lead the way.

One Life to Live

Nora Buchanan. Nora is the woman who slept with her ex, Sam Rappaport, and passed his child off as her husband Boâ€™s child. Even better is the fact that she did it for Boâ€“ whose son was recently killed. That was the rationalization she gave for betraying her husband, she most saintedly did it FOR his sake â€“ all the while knowing that Sam was deeply in love with her and knowing what the emotionally fallout might be. Fortunately (or unfortunately) for all involved, after Bo and Samâ€™s deep pain, it turns out that Matthew was Boâ€™s son after all. Now we have Nora, whoâ€™d been warned/pleaded with/begged not to marry Clint because she didnâ€™t really love him, has now left Clint to be with Bo â€“ during a dark time in Clintâ€™s life.

Once again, another ABC male refers to the cheating lying woman who betrayed him as a whore â€“ I can understand Clintâ€™s rage and his willingness to throw Noraâ€™s past in her face.. I just wish I hadnâ€™t already been overwhelmed with the use of the word â€˜whoreâ€™ from almost every other ABC male before that. Noraâ€™s reaction was still priceless. Sheâ€™s rude and judgmental and has made a habit of telling others why theyâ€™re so unworthy of being loved or trusted. She was stunned that anyone would dare give her the same treatment. I wasnâ€™t crazy about Clintâ€™s choice of words, but Iâ€™m glad that the writers finally allowed someone to point out to Nora what a hypocrite she is.

True to form, Nora didnâ€™t let a little thing like the truth stop her from being who she is. A full scene later, SHE referred to Kim as â€˜that slutâ€™, the â€˜whore in her husbandâ€™s bedâ€™, a â€˜trampâ€™â€¦ uh huhâ€¦ Sweet irony! She was talking to Bo, Clintâ€™s brother, the man sheâ€™d been having an emotional (almost sexual) relationship with and lying to Clint about it when she said itâ€¦ YIKES! Something about the way Bo and Nora are getting together and the pain itâ€™s causing Clint thatâ€™s causing me to want to root for Clint and Kim (a couple Iâ€™d previously referred to as the reincarnation of Asa and Blair).

Somehow, the writers managed to give Clint and Kim depth. Kim was fixated on her â€˜planâ€™ to get Clint into bed to help him forget Nora. Sheâ€™d treated Clint like a feeble and emotionally dependent â€˜old manâ€™ who would be felled by a little bit of a wiggle and giggle. Kim would have loved Asa â€“ being felled by a wiggle and giggle was more his speed. Clint had already had her investigated. He knew about her stripper past, and didnâ€™t care. He also knew that she thought she was gaming him, and he didnâ€™t care. He knew that her plan to â€˜drink him under the tableâ€™ was about taking advantage of himâ€¦ and he didnâ€™t care because he also knew three other things:

1 â€“ He had the truth on his side and still had the upper hand.

2 â€“ That being involved with the townâ€™s â€˜sainted womanâ€™ isnâ€™t a guarantee that youâ€™ll end up with an honest woman whoâ€™ll treat you well.

3 â€“ That Kim isnâ€™t all bad. Her bark is worse than her bite. Despite the fact that there is a risk of turning Kim into a â€˜hooker with a heart of goldâ€™ stereotype, the writers have so far avoided taking her quite that far.

The storyline seems to be shaping up into one in which the person in need of rescue may be KIM, not Clint. Heâ€™s as intent on using her as she was on using him. I hope that doesnâ€™t happen, because despite my exhaustion with female-male May-December romances, thereâ€™s something about this pairing that I like. Nice touch, writers, on having Kimâ€™s plan fail when she underestimated his ability to hold his liquor. BRAVO for letting Clint walk away despite Kimâ€™s offer to let him spend the night and having him warn her to quit while she was ahead. I could root for them as a couple â€“ with Melissa Archerâ€™s Natalie fighting with Kim and making her work to prove her love for Clint. I could <gulp> just as easily root for them developing a strong father-daughter relationship (Oedipal, I know) or have them remain as good friends. Either way, Iâ€™m hoping to see far more of Clint and Kim than Bo and Nora. SONâ€™s CarlID offered this observation:

Itâ€™s interesting to see the fallout of the Bo and Nora reunion. They were a beloved couple many years ago but not only have times changed, many of the people who were in their lives at that time have changed. Itâ€™s like, what if you reunite a supercopule and no one cheered? I donâ€™t mean the fans, I mean the characters in their lives. You donâ€™t have a lot of people endlessly going, â€œYouâ€™re fated to be together,â€ as you do with many other couples on the show. I also think it would be an interesting writing choice if Matthew wasnâ€™t thrilled they were back together and preferred them apart.

Iâ€™ll add one other observation about this storyline. I found Noraâ€™s reaction to seeing Clint with Kim unusual. Kim was the whore in her husbandâ€™s bed? Why did she care, she was dumping him!?!?! Youâ€™d think sheâ€™d want Clint to find someone, ANYONE to take the heat off of her betrayal of Clint. Is it possible that Nora will wake up and realize that her rekindled love for Bo was based on their mutual concern for Matthew and his health issues? Could Nora wake up and realize that she was happier with Clint than she imagined? What happens then? Where does she turn? Does anyone care?

BTW, folks, is it just me, or did Jerry Ver Dorn make Clint his own with this bend in the storyline? JVDâ€™s left me breathless!

Tea Delgado/Blair Manningâ€¦ not whores, theyâ€™re just written to allow Todd Manning to treat them as if they are.

Days of Our Lives

Two words: Carly Manning. Two more words: EPIC FAIL. There are some soap staples I canâ€™t get enough of: scheming liars who are eventually figuratively beaten down and forced to eat their own misery. Bad boys who are only clever by half and outwitted by their victims, victims they eventually fall in love with. Anything to do with corporate intrigue. Good old-fashioned romance. Deep dark family secrets â€“ that have nothing to do with long lost children.

The one plot Iâ€™m pretty freaking tired of is the damsel in distress who canâ€™t get enough of the man she left behind and (oh gosh) if only heâ€™d choose her over his wife and family. He (being the real â€˜whoreâ€™ in this scenario) decides that he canâ€™t leave her to her own fate and risks losing his wife and child/children, while keeping secrets with the damsel in distress. Itâ€™s not a stretch to believe that daytime writers typically set this storyline up to do one of two things: try to make us root for our damsel in distress and if that fails, weâ€™re to hate her as a home-wrecking â€˜whoreâ€™ who broke up a perfectly happy and loving family.

Youâ€™d think that watching her â€˜get hersâ€™ would be satisfying â€“ assuming that the lunkhead goes back to his family and treats his wife as his equal partner, and not his potential mistress. Itâ€™s not. In reality, for fans like me, it only causes us to dislike BOTH partners â€“ the cheating spouse and the idiotic woman who finds his willingness to betray his family a â€˜thrillâ€™ and further evidence that she is the object of his desire, not his wife and family. Sheâ€™s only the next woman to be betrayed when his former victim/spouse becomes the damsel in distress. Itâ€™s all less satisfying because heâ€™ll never â€˜get hisâ€™. Heâ€™ll just become the object of desire for two women â€“ whoâ€™ll continue to fight over him until one of them is exhausted or dead.

Isnâ€™t it time for daytime writers to leave iconic couples alone and find new ways to make them relevant to the audience? Havenâ€™t we seen these storylines play out a million times before? Viewers exiting daytime in droves isnâ€™t enough evidence that we want something more? When did daytime become a genre about deconstructing and destroying rather than building something new or building better and higher on the strong foundation already in place? Where are the powerful female characters who leave us feeling unashamed of being daytime viewers?

If youâ€™ve made it this fair, Iâ€™m sure youâ€™re wondering why Iâ€™ve left poor embattled CBS off the list. Am I sympathetic to the network thatâ€™s lost two soaps in two years? Nope. I just donâ€™t have the room to continue with CBSâ€™ list of maltreated women in daytime. This blog would have to be at least three times as long as it is now. Iâ€™m saving that one for a later date.

Suffice it to say, if daytime really is dead -running on fumes, kicking the bucket, headed for the big one, living on borrowed timeâ€¦ Iâ€™d greatly enjoy being able to celebrate women in daytime before it goes. What do daytime writers have to lose?

With still a few tricks up their sleeves, OLTL writers are making the show as entertaining this month, as last month. WELL DONE!

1. Shaun finally catches his worthless brother and the ever lying Rachel in the act of kissing in public. What heartbreak! Iâ€™d hoped that OLTL would follow GHâ€™s lead and offer an unconventional romantic pairing. GHâ€™s Spinelli and Maxie are clearly mismatched (she the glamazon, he the geek) but they work for whatever reason. Iâ€™d hope that cuddly teddybear Shaun and Princess Rachel would work things out, but not so. Iâ€™m just glad that the writers didnâ€™t spend months keeping the poor guy in the dark while the audience grew increasingly saddened by the deception taking place around him.

Iâ€™m still hoping that Rachel realizes that Greg is a pompus windbag and goes back to Shaun (who wonâ€™t want her back at that point). Rachel, however, wonâ€™t give up and earns her way back into Shaunâ€™s life.

What about Greg? Todd is going to end up dumping Blair soon enough. Why not Greg and Blair? She loves being involved with difficult and self-aggrandizing men. Greg would be perfect for her.

2. Clint and Kim. YEEHAW! This is such a replay of Asa and Blair. Clint reminds me of Asa more and more each day. The drinking, the insecurity masking as toughness, the desperation masking as other things. So, who gets to play the NuMax? Schulyer? Will Kim realize that she wants poor but honest Schulyer after all (ok, so heâ€™s not exactly â€˜NuMaxâ€™)? Will Nora or Viki end up being â€˜Reneeâ€™ for Clint? Poor Clint, alone and lonely, in love with his brotherâ€™s ex wife, foolish enough to believe that putting a ring on her finger will make her love him back. Dudeâ€¦ poor poor Dude.

3. Daniella and Tea? PRICELESS! They have the mother-daughter spark that Blair and Starr lost long ago! The writers took the teeth away from Starr when they foolishly shoved her into the teen pregnancy storyline. Starr has been unrecognizable as Toddâ€™s daughter. She had to become soft and gooey, and a whole lot of foolish, to break out of the role that made Starr such a memorable character. That doesnâ€™t mean that Ive been waiting to see Starr take on Toddâ€™s psychotic tendencies. That would be a tragedy as well. I just wanted her to be shrewd and calculating. I wanted to see Starr protect herself and not take garbage from anyone. Starr lost the edge that use to make her such an enjoyable character. She became a weak and whiny thing, all in the name of â€˜luvâ€™.

What Iâ€™m not looking forward to is competing mother-daughter tag teams. While sibling rivalry makes sense with Toddâ€™s daughters going to war, to have their mothers involved would seem too much like adult women using their daughters to obtain the objects of their affection. Daniella is the â€˜new kidâ€™. Starr has been able to reject her father and cause him to beg for her for her forgiveness â€“ even though he was initially right about Cole, before the writers twisted both Cole and Todd into unrecognizable characters for the sake of â€˜dramaâ€™. Will she as easily walk away from her demented father now that she can be â€˜replacedâ€™? Replaced? Sick? Yes, I knowâ€¦ but thatâ€™s Todd.

By the way, the casting is brilliant for this storyline. KAâ€™s Starr has always looked like the child of Blair and Todd. Kelly Missalâ€™s Daniella, with the to-die-for-hair, makes her look like believable as the child of the Hair goddess, Tea. Daniellaâ€™s temper definitely sells her as Manningâ€™s kid.

4. Talk about continuity! Most shows have difficulty maintaining continuity on their own shows. OLTL maintained continuity between two different shows. Daniel Manache (Tom) was last seen as JJ on As the World Turns. JJ was sent away to (art?) school by his parents â€“ a boarding school. Manache turns up as â€˜Tomâ€™, Matthew and Daniellaâ€™s friend from boarding school. Sweet irony.

As for Matthew and Daniella the potential couple? Can you imagine the nightmare it would cause Bo and Nora to have their son involved with Todd and Teaâ€™s kid? To think, it would never have happened had Bo and Nora not forced Matthew out of the country. Poor Destiny. It seems that she will be the odd girl out, unless the writers are clever in how they write this budding teen romance which will probably loom large next summer. While not everyone is a fan of the character of Destiny, I like her (and even like the actress portraying her â€“ Shennell Edmonds). Edmondâ€™s acting is stiff, and sheâ€™s clearly a novice, but sheâ€™s improving â€“ and anyone who can have such sweet scenes with Tuc Watkinâ€™s David Vickers is winner in my book.

Letâ€™s rid ourselves of all of the bad editors! (if you donâ€™t mind the turn of phrase).Most of what took place on OLTL this past week pleasantly surprised me. Even my well worn remote would like to take this moment to thank the writers for relief. It pretty much had the week off with One Life, since I donâ€™t remember hitting FF once this week. The only big shocker for me this past week were several pretty lousy editing choices, one in particular. Iâ€™ll get to that in a moment.

Soap-heaven help me, I still like John and Marty. The only thing thatâ€™s harder to take than a dark and brooding John McBain is John McBain in love. â€˜Happyâ€™ John and â€˜Broodingâ€™ John are pretty much one in the same. Itâ€™s just at times tough to watch a man who SHOULD be filled with joy behave like a man whose problems could all be solved with the help of a good laxative. Wardrobe, could you PLEASE at least put on a brightly colored shirt under his dark suit jacket and dark coat, to go along with his dark pants and dark shoes so that we know the difference between Brooding John and Joyous John? Thanks!

Johnâ€™s reaction to Marty as she flashed back on her the manipulated-rape sex with Todd was a reminder that there are soap writers who still realize that itâ€™s so much easier for fans to root for good men â€“ we get so few of them in daytime. Many of us still love men who are sensitive to the needs of others, rather than focus on themselves and their own pain. LOVED that moment when John reminded Marty that he was always willing to wait for her â€“ sheâ€™s worth it. LOVED that the writers didnâ€™t follow that scene up with John immediately running to someone else to flirt with or have sex with while Marty was working on her recovery.

The only thing that made the scene even remotely awkward was watching Blair seduce Todd at the same time Marty had difficulty being touched by John because of Toddâ€™s assault of her. If the writers wanted to make some of us squeamish about Todd and Blair, job well done. Otherwise? Bad editing job on this one. It made Todd and Blair seem completely disconnected from the world around them, belligerently insular. They seemed to not care about how much damage had been done to others in their time apart.

Blair, who was disgusted by Toddâ€™s treatment of Marty, seems to have absolutely no qualms about his actions, now. She was disgusted enough before to want to keep his children from him. Now? She canâ€™t keep her hands off of him.

I would much rather have had long soulful talks between the two rather than strip scenes and â€œshame-filledâ€ sex. The problem with the writing for the once magnificent Todd and Blair is that that the writers donâ€™t seem invested in having them break the inch deep-mile wide pattern theyâ€™ve established as part of their courtship. OLTL writers have seem to always bank on the hard work of Kassie DePaiva and Trevor St. John in winning back fans to the â€˜Todd and Blair corner to bring romance back to the show. I think theyâ€™ll have to reconsider, this time. Too much damage has been done and an instant reunion most likely wonâ€™t give them the bump theyâ€™re looking for. How instant is instant in their case? Todd/Blair reunions can be summarized by the following dialogue:

â€œYou hurt meâ€ (Todd to Blair, Blair to Todd, it doesnâ€™t matter).

â€œIâ€™m sorryâ€ (Todd to Blair, Blair to Todd, it doesnâ€™t matter)

â€œStay away from meâ€ (Todd to Blair, Blair to Todd, it doesnâ€™t matter)

â€œYou donâ€™t mean thatâ€ (Todd to Blair, Blair to Todd, it doesnâ€™t matter)

They have sexâ€¦ AND SCENE!

Where is the discussion about what they want and why they want it? What about some insight into why they dragged Marty and John into their psychodrama? How about some part humorous/part dramatic couples counseling for them? What about real consideration about Teaâ€™s feelings? Itâ€™s bad enough that Todd cheated on Tea after she put everything on the line for him, her life included, but he then lied and said that it meant nothing that heâ€™d had sex with Blair. If it wasnâ€™t a lie that having sex with Blair meant nothing to him? It makes his actions even worse. The writers rubbed salt in fansâ€™ wounds by having Todd coldly state to Blair that he was leaving her to go after Tea â€˜because sheâ€™s worth itâ€™.

Hells bells, people, you know that despite Teaâ€™s fault, Iâ€™m a fan of the goddess of grand bitchery but for TODD to state who is â€˜worthyâ€™ and who isnâ€™t? Well that just burns my grits. I would have loved watching Blair get up off the chaise lounge and slap Todd back to his infancy (which would finally allow his external state match his internal state)! Marty, Tea, Blair, his sister Viki, and even his own daughter, Starrâ€¦ just how many women in Llanview are going to end up emotionally scarred thanks to this guy? Taking Todd down the dark road for the sake of pimping â€œStarr and Coleâ€ is a decision that still haunts this show. The writers havenâ€™t been able to find their â€˜Todd mojoâ€™ and get anything right with this character since then.

Despite the detour and bad editing, I enjoy Marty and John.

What else was there to love?

1. Greg turned out to not be a big a jerk as he originally seemed. I liked that he experienced pangs of guilt about running out on Destiny and realizing that heâ€™d hurt her with his actions. I still donâ€™t like the guy enough to have Rachel walk away from Shaun and fall into Dr. Dorkâ€™s waiting arms. I just like the idea of Shawn and Greg working out their differences for their sisterâ€™s sake.

Lovinâ€™ the OLTL writers for giving us this little family. Itâ€™s so unconventional and I canâ€™t wait to see where they go next. Donâ€™t make me eat those words, writers.

2. I uhâ€¦ liked Destiny last week. If youâ€™re shocked, imagine how I feel. Iâ€™m starting to see what the casting directors saw in this kid when they cast her. Sheâ€™s growing in the role and learning to convey a vulnerability thatâ€™s refreshing in a teen character, given the rash of adult-themed storylines daytime writers have been pushing for young characters, lately. It will be interesting to see where the friendship between Destiny and Matthew goes.

3. I uhâ€¦ liked Starr last week. Still in shock here! The discussion between Starr, Cole, and Jessica was so rational and thoughtful, I have to classify it as the high point of my soap watching week! Alderson held her own in scenes with Buddy and Williamson. Scene chewing is not her thing so this emotionally low-key scene felt genuine and believable. I have to admit that the discussion between Jess and Cole sparked my interest most. Er, NO, I donâ€™t want to see them as a couple. Iâ€™m giving kudos to the writers for creating such a layered scene. Both made the connection that they were both â€˜in recoveryâ€™ and made poor choices because of an inordinate amount of pain, but that they both needed to take responsibility for their own actions. Both Jess and Cole realized that they had to forgive others as they needed to be forgiven. For a brief and shining moment, I felt that I could honestly tell my friends who donâ€™t know that I watch soaps about the show â€¦ well done, writers, well done! It was good enough for prime timeâ€¦ ğŸ˜‰ Ouch?

4. Wish I could give a crap about the Stacy storyline, but I donâ€™t. I donâ€™t even care who Rexâ€™s father is any moreâ€¦ just.not.interested!

While Starr moved one step closer to being a â€˜real momâ€™, Gigi took a step back for me. (Wait, Iâ€™m getting to itâ€¦ thereâ€™s something I like about this storyline, hang on)â€¦ It was odd to watch her encourage Shaneâ€™s hatred of Aunt Stacy no matter how much of a low life Stacy has been.

I had to wonder if there wasnâ€™t a unconscious attempt to warn fans about the perils of being a young mother â€“ since it appears that theyâ€™re avoiding that â€˜lessonâ€™ of young parenthood with Starr and Cole. Gigi applauding Shaneâ€™s comic book character (skanky Stacy? Sleazy Stacy?) REEKED of an immature mother dragging her child into her babyâ€™s daddy drama. A mature mother would have told Shane that his feelings of anger are appropriate, but that itâ€™s also appropriate to feel sorry for Stacy for what sheâ€™s become and to hold out hope for her. The Gigi-Shane scenes skeeved me out a bit, I gottaâ€™ admit.
